name: NPR
text:
President Trump declared himself "a law-and-order president" as he delivered remarks in opposition to the ongoing demonstrations, describing the unrest as "acts of domestic terrorism."
https://t.co/2uZ0GYgAxS

name: NPR
text:
‚ÄúI think at the time of the Rodney King beating it was easier to view it as an isolated incident or as a few bad apples,‚Äù says USC law professor Jody David Armour.

‚ÄúBut now, over time, we see a persistent and pervasive pattern.‚Äù https://t.co/cu9XaZxRMy

name: NPR
text: "It's not just about one or two instances. ... We continually are separated from American society. We're treated as if we're less than." Black demonstrators told @CapRadioNews about why these protests are important to them. https://t.co/N3uwulvM5G

name: NPR
text:
George Floyd‚Äôs death was ruled a homicide, according to a new official autopsy report.

The medical examiner said Floyd's heart and lungs stopped functioning "while being restrained" by police.
https://t.co/oqV4KKYNst

name: NPR
text: Adm. Brett Giroir will be "demobilized" from his role overseeing coronavirus testing in mid-June and going back to his regular job at the Department of Health and Human Services. https://t.co/KYxXeb8Hd2

name: NPR
text:
President Trump threatened to deploy the military to states that don't quell violent protests.

But to do that, he would need to invoke what's known as the Insurrection Act of 1807.
https://t.co/z9PLOI07iu

name: NPR
text: RT @WBEZ: ‚ÄúOur communities already been blighted,‚Äù activist William Calloway bellowed. ‚ÄúThis is years of frustration. We are tired. We are frustrated. We don‚Äôt want our community to be destroyed. Why we gotta be destructive to be heard?‚Äù https://t.co/fK0PaSUU4T

name: NPR
text:
At least a dozen Facebook employees, some in senior positions, have openly condemned the company's lack of action on President Trump's posts ‚Äî and CEO Mark Zuckerberg's defense of that decision.
https://t.co/oLt4fsETvM

name: NPR
text:
Former President Obama writes that it isn't a choice between protesting and voting: "We have to do both."

"The elected officials who matter most in reforming police departments and the criminal justice system work at the state and local levels," he says.
https://t.co/tyiNqROZhs

name: NPR
text:
Brit Bennett's new novel centers on two light-skinned African American sisters ‚Äî one of whom "passes" for white. 

Throughout a compelling novel, Bennett offers pointed observations about privilege and racism. 
https://t.co/p9lsK7b0qs

name: NPR
text:
Schools in the U.K. reopened for the first wave of students ‚Äî despite concerns from parents and teachers that reopening is not yet safe.
https://t.co/YMD5eUOmuK

name: NPR
text:
"I know I can't come back from this," says Safia Munye, whose Minneapolis restaurant was destroyed last week in protests over George Floyd's death. 

"But this can be replaced. George's life cannot. ... I hope he gets justice."
https://t.co/TuQKWVXHf8

name: NPR
text:

‚ÄúBut now, over time, we see a persistent and pervasive pattern.‚Äù https://t.co/oHoQZ4IVNx

name: NPR
text:
38% of kids from America's lowest-income homes and 35% of kids in special education are doing little or no remote learning, a new survey finds.

By contrast, 83% of kids from families making over $100,000 a year are doing it every day.
https://t.co/2CxM26y2fx

name: NPR
text:
Dozens of public health and disease experts have signed an open letter in support of the nationwide anti-racism protests.

"White supremacy is a lethal public health issue that predates and contributes to COVID-19," they wrote.
https://t.co/EewPNgDSu3

name: NPR
text: The upbraiding from the White House didn't sit well with many governors, who have been busy responding to clashes between protesters and police in dozens of cities sparked by the death of George Floyd after a Minneapolis police officer knelt on his neck. https://t.co/FdZc8cqx2B

name: NPR
text:
Athletes are speaking up about racism ‚Äî from activists like Kareem Abdul-Jabbar to apolitical figures like Michael Jordan and Carson Wentz. 

This solidarity is bringing awareness to peaceful protests in sports ‚Äî and what happens when they're ignored. https://t.co/BbS7GMIr69

name: NPR
text: Even before the economic downturn, the Twin Cities had some of the most abysmal numbers on racial inequality in the nation, @planetmoney finds, creating the backdrop for the rising sense of unfairness and anger we've seen over the last week. https://t.co/ZX3zba4pU1

name: NPR
text: As the picture of who is impacted by the coronavirus becomes clearer, it's evident that the pandemic is disproportionately affecting minorities ‚Äî and that existing socioeconomic inequities like wage gaps were major factors in determining who gets sick. https://t.co/mniINBiVTc
